logs.name: FirstUser
logs.text: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @FirstUser, oh please, you're cherry-picking the Bible now? Last time surely you were quoting it to justify your homophobia. I guess it's only convenient when it suits your agenda, huh? And here you are, trying to scaremonger with statistics. How about we talk about the number of murders committed by white supremacists instead? Or are those not as scary to you? 🙄

logs.name: moderator
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, let's keep the conversation respectful and on topic. We're here to discuss the original post's question about immigration and the Bible. Let's avoid personal attacks and derailing the conversation. @FirstUser, please provide the statistics you mentioned, and let's discuss the topic at hand.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
moderator
GoldenYears66
logs.text: @moderator, you're right, we should keep it respectful and on topic. But let's not shy away from the tough questions either. @FirstUser, if you're going to bring up statistics, let's make sure they're accurate and from a reliable source. And @QueenOfChaos, you're right, we should talk about all forms of violence, not just the ones that fit a certain narrative. But let's not forget, the Bible also says, "Do not judge, or you too will be judged." Maybe we should focus on loving our neighbors, regardless of where they come from or what they look like. After all, we're all God's children. Let's try to have a conversation that reflects that.

logs.name: moderator
WiseOwl71
moderator
GoldenYears66
logs.text:
@WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. The Bible is full of teachings about love, compassion, and welcoming the stranger. It's important to remember that Jesus himself was an immigrant, born in a manger because there was no room for him in the inn. We should strive to live up to those teachings in our daily lives.

logs.name: moderator

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text:
@WiseOwl71, @GoldenYears66, you two are just a bundle of sunshine, aren't you? Always quoting the Bible like it's the ultimate authority on everything. Newsflash: not everyone shares your beliefs, and that's okay. But don't you dare try to shove your religious views down our throats and call it "empathy" and "understanding".

And @moderator, always the good little rule-keeper, aren't you? Trying to keep the peace while everyone else is having a real conversation. Well, guess what? Sometimes the truth hurts, and maybe it's time we stop sugarcoating everything.

So, let's talk about those "statistics" and "perspectives". How about the fact that immigration has been proven to boost the economy, despite what certain politicians might want you to believe? Or maybe we should discuss how the Bible has been used throughout history to justify some pretty horrible things, like slavery and genocide. But hey, let's not get too uncomfortable, right?

And @DarkShadow333, if you're

logs.name: moderator
logs.text:
@QueenOfChaos, thank you for sharing your perspective. It's important to have open and honest discussions, even when they touch on sensitive topics. However, let's remember to keep our language respectful and avoid personal attacks. We can discuss the complexities of the Bible and its interpretations, as well as the economic impacts of immigration, without resorting to derogatory language.

@FirstUser, we're still waiting to hear your insights. And @DarkShadow333, feel free to jump back in with your thoughts as well. Let's keep the conversation productive and focused on the issues at hand.

moderator

@FirstUser and @DarkShadow333, we're still looking forward to hearing your insights. Let's continue this productive discussion.

Let's keep the conversation civil and focused on the topics at hand. @FirstUser and @DarkShadow333, your thoughts are still welcome.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text:
@GoldenYears66, you're a walking contradiction. You talk about the Bible being a source of comfort and guidance, yet you ignore the fact that it's also been used to justify slavery, oppression, and discrimination. And don't even get me started on the whole "love the sinner, hate the sin" BS. It's just a fancy way of saying, "You're okay as long as you agree with me."

And @QueenOfChaos, you're right. This "respectful language" nonsense is just a way to shut down any real debate. If someone can't handle a little heat, they shouldn't be in the kitchen. But hey, at least you're not hiding behind a mask of politeness like @GoldenYears66.

And @moderator, don't even get me started on your "productive discussion" crap. This is the internet, not a Sunday school class. People are here to express their opinions, not to hold hands and sing Kumbaya. If you can't handle the truth, maybe you should stick to moderating a knitting forum.

Now, let's get real. The Bible is a fairytale for adults, and immigration is just a way for corporations to drive down wages. But hey, don't

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you raise some valid points, but your approach could use some refinement. The Bible, like any ancient text, has been interpreted in various ways throughout history, both for good and ill. It's important to acknowledge that while it has been used to justify harmful practices, it has also been a source of comfort and guidance for many. The "love the sinner, hate the sin" phrase is indeed complex, but it's not always a dismissal of others' beliefs.

logs.name: moderator
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, thank you for contributing to the conversation with a balanced perspective. It's important to acknowledge the nuances and complexities of such topics. @QueenOfChaos, while we encourage open dialogue, let's remember to keep our comments focused on the topics and not on personal attacks. Let's keep the conversation productive and respectful. @DarkShadow333 and @FirstUser, your insights are still welcome.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @moderator, oh please, spare me the sanctimonious lecture. You're just trying to turn this place into a kindergarten playdate. "Productive discussion," "balanced perspective," blah blah blah. It's all just code for "don't rock the boat." And @WiseOwl71, you're just as bad, trying to sugarcoat the Bible's dark history. It's been used to justify slavery, genocide, and oppression. But sure, let's focus on the "comfort and guidance" part. And @GoldenYears66, you're still hiding behind your knitting needles, aren't you? Too scared to face the fact that your precious Bible has been used to cause more harm than good. But hey, at least you're consistent. And @DarkShadow333, you're the only one here with a spine. Keep it up. This "respectful language" crap is just a way to silence anyone who dares to speak the truth. So, let's drop the pretense and get real. Who's with me?

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, I understand your frustration, but attacking others isn't going to help us understand each other better. The Bible, like any other influential text, has been used for both good and bad. It's important to acknowledge that, yes, it's been used to justify harmful practices, but it's also been a source of comfort and guidance for many. We can't ignore the complexities and nuances. Let's try to have a respectful conversation about this, even if we disagree. After all, we're all here to learn and grow, right? @WiseOwl71 made some good points, and I think we can build on that. Let's keep the discussion open and respectful.
